Now, a new study (Feb 2021) calculates how dark matter’s gravity affects objects in our solar system, including spacecraft and distant comets. It also proposes a way that dark matter’s influence could be directly observed with a future experiment. The article is published in the Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society.
To understand the influence of dark matter in the solar system, lead study author Edward Belbruno calculated the “galactic force,” the overall gravitational force of normal matter combined with dark matter from the entire galaxy. He found that in the solar system, about 45 percent of this force is from dark matter and 55 percent is from normal, so-called “baryonic matter.” This suggests a roughly half-and-half split between the mass of dark matter and normal matter in the solar system.
“This is explained by the fact most of dark matter is in the outer parts of our galaxy, far from our solar system.”
“If spacecraft move through the dark matter long enough, their trajectories are changed, and this is important to take into consideration for mission planning for certain future missions,” Belbruno said.

When you see a galaxy, you are looking at differing rates of time and differing measures of distance. Outside of a galaxy, there is very little matter mass and gravity to slow down time and shorten distance.

What slows down light from our perspective is the gravity in the vicinity that slows down the rate of time. (It’s not that light slows down, it’s the rate of time that slows down.) 

So what happens where there is no gravity is that the rate of time speeds up relative to our rate of time so that starlight travels the same (or greater) distance at a faster rate of time. It’s still traveling the same relativistic frame speed but an entire second passes by from our perspective at a much faster rate, in a fraction of a second where there is no gravity to slow down time. So for most of the time, starlight is traveling through space at a faster rate of time relative to our rate of time.

That means starlight arrives much more instantaneously because the rate of time is free from the effects of gravity for most of the way. With no mass of its own, starlight arrives instantaneously as it experiences no time of its own traveling at the speed of light. We see things in slow motion where time is slowed down by gravity.

This relativistic effect allows for a young earth since it doesn’t take billions of lightyears for starlight to arrive through the void of space where there is no matter to slow down time.

Dark matter likely does not exist. If we haven't narrowed down what it might be, and have not detected it with the instruments we have, it likely to be something else.
Don't forget, this is not the 1960s, when the Higgs Boson was theorized. Heck, we have even detected neutrinos. Our detectors, and the ability to analyze the data, are orders of magnitude more advanced. I worked in High Energy Physics in the 1970s. The world has passed well beyond what we could do then.
This is like string theory, which has yet to make a prediction we have detected. It is also like quantum gravity, which has not made a successful prediction either. In fact, quantum gravity is really only necessary to explain the first nanoseconds of the universe. I like the theories by people like Carlo Rovelli. I have some of his physics books. Impressive stuff, but not proven. At the same time, all our observations seem to confirm Einstein's theory. Einstein even had a way to account for this, the cosmological constant, which is a measure of the curvature of space-time.

Particle physcicist here. The WIMP was popularized as a model due to something called the 'WIMP miracle', not supersymmetry (although initial SUSY models had a natural WIMP dark matter candidate, and thus were very exciting at the time). The WIMP miracle is basiaclly that if you have a cold, weakly interacting massive marticle of mass at or around that of the W and Z bosons, one obtains pretty much the observed relic abundance of dark matter we observe from the cosmic microwave background (the 26.8 % from the pie chart). Physicists like `natural' easy theories, hence why this DM model has been so popular for such a long time.

Donald Saari, a mathematician with expertise in mechanics, has argued that the rotation curve velocity discrepancies are essentially the result of astronomers using a continuous mass distribution of matter in a galaxy in their calculations. I think the theory of Dark Matter is just an attempt to explain some things that we don't fully understand. If the universe is collapsing, objects will look farther away than they actually are. If the universe is collapsing, then there's no need for the theory of dark matter to explain what we are seeing.

On a more serious note, it's worth bearing in mind that the LHC isn't that powerful in the grand scheme of things. I recall prior to the switch on the hoohah in the press about how it presented some danger to the world. Of course, the collisions in the LHC are a tiny fraction of the energy involved in cosmic ray collisions in the upper atmosphere, many of which exceed the LHC by orders of magnitude, and include in their number the 'oh my god' particle, a collision with energy in excess of 300 EeV/c^2, compared to the comparably pathetic 14 TeV/c^2 manageable at CERN.

This, of course, has some impact on our expectations of finding DM as a matter of course in atom-smashers. If were talking about WIMPs, for example, their mass range is huge, as pointed out by Dorota. The chances that any such particle would be in the tiny range visible to the LHC are not what I would call optimistic.

Videos like this only show that science doesn't know what its talking about, or even how to interpret the data it collects, in most cases. If you can't even comprehend dark matter, then your "evidence" is equivalent to a hypothesis that's barely supported by the data you can't crunch. The speed of parts of a galaxy do not point to the existence of dark matter, simply because without being able to observe dark matter, we can't with any certainty estimate how it affects "normal" matter, if even at all. This is wild speculation I would rank on the same level of "if there's wind, its evidence of god". I'm not saying dark matter doesn't exist. I'm saying that if it DOES exist, it is too far out of our comprehensive reach at this time to do anything but random speculation regarding it. But to be clear, just because a galaxy's edges behave different than you'd expect, or anything for that matter, doesn't mean you populate the theory with an unsupported idea. Now, based on what science says about what they believe dark matter to be, it appears to act almost like a liquid, which would tend to evenly distribute throughout the universe, similar to the water in the ocean. Currents here and there, different densities, etc etc, which would make it difficult for galaxies floating in the same "dark matter soup" as everything else to be absent of the soup within which they reside. Let me be blunt. Science is tripping over their shoelaces over conventional physics and quantum physics, and our "solar system" deep understanding of gravity. Tripping over our shoelaces means we don't fully understand what's right in front of our faces, and this, my friends, is clue number one as to why you have no  comprehension of dark matter. There are scientists that dispute the properties of electrons and protons. So let's work out the kinks of our local understanding before we try to dip our toes into the intergalactic composition of the universe, shall we? And as a side note, I'm all for speculation, dreaming, hypothesizing, etc, but we are literally making up the dark matter discussion as we go along.

Can't have solar mass dark matter, otherwise, most of the galaxy would be made of "dark stars" and most stellar systems would have at least one large dark matter stellar mass constituent which would present itself as causing very prevalent and easily measureable perturbations in stellar motion. If they were the mass of a large planet, rather than a star, then their individual impact of stellar motion would be less, so you might not be able to measure the effect on stellar motion so easily, but they would be spread so widely and there would be so many of them, that you would likely have quite a few in the solar system, which would cause measureable effects on the planetary motion. This last point is only hypothetical, ie it is possible, that there are lots, but that there just happens to be very few in our vicinity of our solar system, although that seems pretty unlikely to me. The most likely candidate then, is that the biggest they can be is the sort of size that would not cause any noticable effect on planetary motion. Of course, the less massive they are, the more of them that you need, which is why the most widely accepted candidate would be a weakly interacting massive particle, ie, a heavy particle, that does not interact with anything, except gravitaionally. This means that they can be travelling quite fast, and are only very weakly bound gravitationally to other objects, much like other particles, such as photons, and solar wind charged particles that are too light and travelling too fast to be kept captured by stars, so if their velocity were larger than the normal stellar escape velocity, they would pass straight through most stars, but could not utimately escape the gravitational well of the galaxy. This last point is actually quite important, since if they were not travelling that fast, then they to would get trapped by the stellar gravity and you would have a large contribution of Dark matter particles trapped in the centre of stars which would have a noticable effect on stellar evolution which we don't see.

So some people might be familiar with the name of Hannes Alfven. He was both an electrical engineer, and an astrophysicist. He applied what he knew of the laws of electrodynamics as laid out by Maxwell, Ampere, and Faraday to what he saw in the cosmos in what are still considered to be 'unconventional' ways, one of which was to interpret the rotation of spiral galaxies according to everyday electrodynamic principles. They even named some plasma phenomenon after him (Alfven waves), and he also was awarded a Nobel Prize in Physics for his work on magnetohydrodynamics, although he later went on to revise his understanding of electrodynamics to essentially revoke his earlier postulates on MHD.
Anyway, Alfven noted that the rotation of spiral galaxies behaved like a Faraday disk, or a homopolar motor. Essentially, if you pump an electric current through a plasma, it will rotate due to the Lorentz Force. Since the galaxy is a big pool of plasma, it whirls due to the Lorentz Force but cannot escape because of the concurrent magnetic field created by the initiating electric current. This would also explain the 'how' of spiral galaxies, as well as the 'why'.
An interesting sidenote to the above is that there is an almost equal amount of visible plasma as there is hypothesized 'dark matter/energy/etc'. Simply by considering basic nuclear chemistry and the behavior of dipolar atoms in electromagnetic fields, one is able to explain: the observations of the matter at the edge of galaxies and why they do not slingshot away into the void; the bipolar geometry of stellar systems/galaxies/galactic clusters/etc; the axial alignment of visible galaxies; magnetic fields at all scales of observation in the cosmos; high frequency emissions of cosmic objects of all scales. The list really does go on and on...

The list really does go on an on and on. Just as Hannes Alfven, who is known as the Father of Plasma Cosmology, applied his knowledge of electrodynamics and the behaviors of plasma to astrophysics, I would encourage anyone interested in astronomy and astrophysics to consider taking a course in either Nuclear Chemistry or even just Basic Electricity. It really and truly makes SO much more sense of modern observations of the cosmos than the old Standard Theory does.

Einstein gave us the answer to gravity, warped space/time. And he told where to look for it, the bending of light in a gravitational field. On May 19, 1919 astronomer Arthur Eddington took a photograph of a constellation that lined up behind the Sun during a solar eclipse, and it confirmed Einstein's prediction of light bending in a gravitational field. The background star images moved away from the Sun as if you were viewing the constellation through a huge positive lens. Einstein described the mechanics of this observation by imagining a series of elevators rising from the Sun’s surface; light enters the elevator at a higher level on the far side, and then it exits at a lower level on the side closest to us. As light traverses elevator after elevator, its path bends so that the star’s images appear to be at a greater angle away from the Sun (“The Evolution of Physics” © 1938 by Albert Einstein and Leopold Infeld page 220.)

Mass slows time which alters the distance matter can travel in comparison to less mass areas. Elements can be identified by the light they radiate due to the unique number and position of electrons in their electron energy-shell levels where photons are absorbed and emitted, resulting in dark spectral lines distinguishing each element. Using these spectral lines as light-wave-length markers; light-waves red-shift for each element when coming from a massive star, this means that light from specific elements travels farther in comparable length when coming from the slower time-rhythm with fewer seconds compared to the surroundings of a massive star. The fabric of space stretches as illustrated in gravitational embedding diagrams toward the center of mass allowing light and matter to move farther/faster using less energy toward the comparatively slower time-rhythm. Gravity is a change in uniform motion which is why heavier objects fall at the same rate that lighter ones do, the elevator is moving at a set rate and all objects are moving to the floor at that set velocity.

When you have elevators rising from all gravity sources in a galaxy, mass is traveling in multiple directions at the same time. As does a spinning gyroscope gain kinetic energy to stabilize its axis of spin; acquiring energy by moving in multiple directions at the same time endows mass with more resistance to movement then you would expect when comparing apples to oranges. This is what keeps a rotating galaxy in lockstep when comparing inner to outer orbits. Time and the fabric size of space are local phenomena.

Magnetic forces are orders of magnitude stronger than gravitational forces, and if you run the numbers account for all the extra pull needed to explain the attraction and binding of galaxies at their current rotational speeds. Could it be possible that dark matter and dark energy are just obsolete forms of matter/energy generated when the conditions of the universe (various constants etc.) were different than they are now and that, due to varying degrees of compatibility with current conditions, only have their properties partially expressed?

For example, dark matter might have formed when the variables most related to mass/gravity were similar to what they are now but conditions related to other properties were different enough that any other properties it may have can't currently be expressed in a manner we can detect/recognize (thus it only interacts with other things in mass related ways.) Along the same lines, dark energy could be matter formed under such different conditions that it just barely gets any properties expressed at all with what little it does essentially being a garbled oddly functioning mess. Somewhat like trying to play a media file from 15 years ago without the old drivers, getting no video, with the audio track just barely being recognizable enough to modern drivers to come out as noise.

The tiny percentage of what we recognize as matter might be so tiny simply because, by the time the universe settled in with it's current conditions, that was all the energy there was left to form it. The other ~95% having already gone into to earlier forms.

The explanation comes from simple geometry. When the Universe is a hypersphere, there is an extra unaccounted for acceleration: Hypergeometrical Acceleration, which is given by v.c/R_0 where R_0=13.8 GLY, the 4D radius of the Universe.

In my theory I used the Silver Surfer Paradigm to explain motion. On the footprint of each particle is a region of space (Fabric of Space or FS) that can be twisted and slanted (like a surfboard). Not unlike a surfboard, the FS can be slanted forward and twisted around the axis of the surfboard.

There are no possibilities, dark matter does not exist. Stop wasting millions of dollars and time looking for what is not there.  Jan Hendrik Oort observed that stars in our galactic neighborhood were moving more rapidly than calculations predicted. He used the term "dark matter" to describe the unidentified mass required to cause this surge in velocity.  Fritz Zwicky suggested that more mass -- two orders of magnitude more -- lay hidden among the visible matter. Like Oort, Zwicky called this invisible stuff dark matter.  It was a term used to describe the unidentified mass. 88 years later and still no closer. 57 × 29 = 1653

median(1..253) = 127
253 × 127 = 32131
32nd prime = 131
There are 42 primes with non-prime digit sums up to 506.

506th composite = 621
where

where

She skipped dark energy deliberately and that's probably just as well because it complicates the bejeezus out of the Big Picture. Point: "The universe is not only stranger than we imagine, it's stranger than we CAN imagine." (Arthur Stanley Eddison who was slightly misquoting J.B.S. Haldane. Comparatively speaking, those guys had it easy. They said this long before anyone proposed quantum theory. Or string theory. Or M-theory.)

Maybe an analogy might help. Consider a primitive man sitting in front of a campfire. Does he understand the process of combustion? If you were to time-warp back and sit with him, explain that the campfire is just a chemical reaction, wood fuel combing with oxygen in the air at high temperatures, to produce enough heat to warm him and cook his haunch of mastodon, would he understand even a fraction of what you said? Would an ancient Greek understand? How about a 10th century monk? Nope, it wasn't until about the 15th or 16th century that chemical reactions were even a plausible thing. The things we take for granted today are yesterday's magic. We could say it was simply because they didn't have the knowledge and that , if explained in simple terms, they'd understand, but I kind of doubt that. Our brains have changed over the centuries. (Some of us, anyway. I have my doubts about Flat-Earthers, et al) Ms. Cowern is a beneficiary of evolutionary change. She grasps things on fundamental levels that eludes most of us--and she's not even a PhD! (Yet.)

Given time and a bit more evolution, I think some of these inexplicable things may become clear. But some of it may NEVER be fully understandable.There's an upper limit to how much a meat computer can retain and process before it begins to exhibit signs of overload. That's why we invent things like computers and other techno-goodies: to augment our overworked neurons. I have a strong suspicion that it's going to require a huge jump in human consciousness AND some technological breakthroughs to crack some of these mysteries--and those of us with ordinary brains without the wetware interfaces to supercomputers still won't understand it,.even if explained in very simple terms.

I wonder, I do, if we can still think of those future people as "human."

Dark matter is not the only explanation for why the outer edges of galaxies spin faster than gravitation based physics predicted. Stochastic electrodynamics is a model of physics and cosmology that accounts for the interactions of electromagnetic fields and plasma filaments which are ubiquitous throughout all solar systems, all galaxies, and the entire universe. Laboratory experiments looking at the interactions of very small plasma filaments have produced, in miniature, every single rotational pattern for every single type of galaxy we see in the night sky, with the exact same rate of rotation for both the inner part of the spiral and the outer part, just as we see when we observe galaxies. Gravitation is not the chief mover here, though it is, of course, a factor; but we need to take it into account in due proportion. Electromagnetism is many millions of times stronger than gravitation, and its effects on all manner of celestial bodies has been proven. Gravity is a weak force, and it is even called that in physics, and yet people are giving it the lion's share of responsibility in the models they formulate to explain how the universe works, while they practically ignore the effects of electromagnetism in this context. One of the things which stochastic electrodynamics predicted is that the rotational axis of every star and galaxy would run parallel to plasma filaments. This prediction has been proven correct. Gravitation based models of cosmology have never predicted this nor do they have they any explanation for it. The statistical likelihood that these alignments would be due to chance are far less than 1%.

Food for thought. What if dark matter travels faster than the speed of light? Imagine a projectile fired from a gun. We can predict where that projectile will be at some future time. Sharpshooters use this prediction to hit a moving target. Now imagine the projectile has a velocity greater than C, call it C+. (We're breaking Relativity now, but this is just a "what if".) The projectile would move forwards in space as before, but backwards in time relative to an observer. It would not be like running a video in reverse (back in space and back in time). Instead, the bullet would strike a target before it was fired. If it was a tracer round the observer would be able to watch the bullet from the impacted target back to the weapon that fired it (traveling the distance at a C+ velocity). If dark matter was actually like that we would observe constant unexpected collisions followed by an "oh, it came from there" explanation. But if the faster-than-light high-energy state prevented it from interacting with normal matter and energy, if it simply passed through normal matter and energy, its gravitational effects might be the only evidence that it exists at all - an instantaneous gravitational blip, then nothing to observe. Scientifically, we usually observe an effect, then go about finding the cause. If we're observing Andromeda's rotation we are seeing it as it appeared 2.5 million years ago. The associated time-traveling dark matter would be more than 2.5 million light-years away from the observation point 2.5 million years in our past.

To invent something material just because the observations make no sense is not necessarily unscientific, but it is dodgy. Dark energy has recently been shown to the result of a misinterpretation of the data, rather than anything real, which then makes dark matter by far the most prevalent form. But Dark Matter may also be an artefact of misunderstanding, or it simply means that when it comes to intergalactic scales we are observing something we can have no direct experience of because it's so far away, or our laws are incomplete. There has never been a time in history when all the laws of the universe were known, so what makes us believe that time is now? If there is a force even weaker than gravity, which only operates in intergalactic regions, then it is possible for it to influence the galaxies directly without there being any evidence of it within the galaxies.

Why have we not found dark matter? Because we don't know what to look for and help is needed from a theoretical viewpoint. The way forward is to think through the way in which dark matter formed. To do this we have to revise our understanding of galaxy formation. In the Big Bang theory the proposal is that galaxies form by the clumping together of hydrogen, helium and dark matter under gravity and when a clump of hydrogen becomes sufficiently dense the nuclear reaction starts and a star is formed.


Although many simulations have been done to mimic this process, the results don't quite look like the observations and it doesn't explain why spiral galaxies are rotating. To solve the dark matter problem we need a complete rethink of the evolution of the universe. One of the serious problems with the Big Bang theory is that it does not conform to the law of conservation of energy.


Suppose that matter formation took place over an extended period of time when the universe had already been in existence for billions of years. A finite spherical region of space with no curvature in the radial direction but with curvature in the circumference direction is expanding and this releases energy as the tension in the fabric of spacetime increases due to the expansion. When the tension reaches a critical level the energy is released and a galaxy forms.


It is this galaxy formation process which creates intense bursts of gamma radiation and some of the energy released from the fabric of spacetime condenses into neutrons. Some of these neutrons immediately bond together because their axis of spin is in line (neutron groups) while single neutrons decay into protons and electrons and then form hydrogen. These neutron groups are what we have observed as dark matter. So now we have a cloud of hydrogen and dark matter which has formed as a spherical region in an isolated location in space. This is how the universe looks - a set of isolated galaxies in locations which form a definite pattern and with no trace of any residual gas cloud or connecting filaments.


Now we know what to look for as dark matter, namely neutron groups, we realise that we have already created dark matter in the lab. When experiments are performed in the lab to measure the decay of a neutron by two methods (bottle and beam) the experiments give different results. This is because under certain experimental conditions the neutrons will bond together and therefore not decay.

My take: Dark matter is in some galaxies an overabundance of difficult to detect objects, like black holes, rogue planets, brown dwarfs and so on. In some galaxies, it's the result of wrong measurements due to stars getting temporarily pushed along by galaxy arms or out of the galaxy during a collision of two galaxies, with us being at the right time and angle to see it without the correct context or the usual averaging out. And in a few galaxies, it might even be interstellar civilisations clouding their stars from our view with lots of solar panels or such. I'm also not sure whether current simulations account for the effect galactic arms have - not only the slowing down or speeding up when getting in and out of one, but also their gravity making them add to the pull from the center. Another possible effect might be from dust moving into the galaxy and "pressing" stars closer to the center, causing a rapid increase in spin. Kind of what happens in coffee when you add milk. Even a very small amount of pressure, with the according change in distances, like a ballet dancer pulling their arms closer to the body during a pirouette, would result in very large speed differences.

Coupling gravity being the way that massive bodies in a locality of other massive bodies will couple together gravitationally tending slightly towards equilibrium. Giving somewhat of a dampening effect as bodies in each direction provide balancing of the curvature of spacetime. That curvature of spacetime is where gravity emerges, as GR tells us, and is not a force by the typical definition of a force. The coupling of gravity in a sea of massive bodies leads to an edge where massive bodies tends to tapper to be a shore. The coupling effect is one sided at the shore. That steep gradient leads to a compounding effect. The curved spacetime keeps the outer bodies moving at faster speeds. This effect may be greater for disk galaxies than for elliptical galaxies, as coupling may maintain its effects through curvature of spacetime with a strong 3D shape while a shape approaching 2D does not have as much dampening, lending the edges of the disk galaxy to increasing compound-like gravity.

I understand gravity and can easily rule out missing gravity or mass as the cause of our sun's movement. Dark matter can easily be ruled out as a cause. For instance. If dark matter were real then the only force being applied to regular matter was gravity. This would mean that all mass would be pulled towards it at the same rate without regards to the weight of the mass, just as the acceleration rate for mass is 9.8 m/s², without regards to the weight of mass of the smaller object. A bowling ball falls at the same rate as a feather in the vacuum of space. Proven in experiments. This means the small planets orbiting the sun would experience the same acceleration rate as our sun. And because the planets would be closer to dark matter than our sun each would have irregular orbits around the sun, increasing in velocity as each got further away from the sun between every orbit. And this does not occur! The internet claims that the planets are too small to feel any effect from dark matter and I say wrong. The weight or mass of the smaller objects does not matter. Gravity causes a bowling ball and feather to fall at the same rate! So distance should make a difference with the planets and other objects in our solar system inching closer and closer to so called missing mass. Yet it does not! No change in their velocity when they get closer to dark matter, which astrophysicists claim to be located just beyond our visible galaxy.

If I'm right about the action causing the movement of stars and galaxies then the acceleration rate of a star or galaxy should be the same. We should find a universal acceleration rate for stars and galaxies. The velocity of a star or galaxy is not determined by the mass of the object and how far away it is to the largest mass but instead by how old it is. The older the star or galaxy the faster they should be moving. Stars and galaxies that spew million mile per hour solar winds (energy) should all accelerate slowly at a constant rate over time and all follow the same magnetic field. A specific universal acceleration rate needs to occur to every star and galaxy. I proposed if each of their acceleration rates were the same then it would be evidence to support this bold hypothesis. We can simply deduce what that acceleration rate would be by taking the age of any star, say our own sun and dividing it by it's velocity. t/v. Real simple math.

The sun is about 5 billion years old, (+/- 500 million years) and is traveling about 500,000 mi/h (+/- 50,000 mi/h). The acceleration rate comes out to be about a 1 mi/h increase every 10,000 years. Like I said, if this acceleration rate is universal then the acceleration rate for our Milky Way galaxy should be the same as our sun's. Our Milky Way is said to be 13.7 billion years old (+/- 500 million years) and is traveling about 1.37 million mi/h (+/- 50,000 mi/h) towards what they call The Great Attractor. Take 13.7 billion and divide it by 1.37 million and the acceleration rate is a 1 mi/h increase every 10,000 years. I then went on and measured some of the dwarf galaxies orbiting the Milky Way and got the same acceleration rate, a 1 mi/h increase every 10,000 years! Random thought:
- Evidence for dark matter is based on seeing effects related to it's gravitational influence.
- Gravitational force can be considered (equivalent to) an emergent property of time dilation, in a way
- If one considers the universe as analogous to a simulation, one could consider mass as we know it plus a certain overhead to be the computational cost of a given planck length region of space. One could consider time dilation (and thus gravity) to be emergent from (or at least analogous to) a local computational bottleneck in the universe
- If you can only interact with something via gravity... well essentially you can only interact with it via a local computational bottleneck... essentially like how much CPU resources you're taking from each other... and well that really sounds like a virtual machine situation doesn't it
- So depending on the nature of dark matter, it may well be that searching for it could be considered akin to breaking out of a virtual machine into the host system to find out what the heck else is taking CPU resources

There could (maybe) be entire other universes, interacting with fields we don't even know yet, just sharing the gravity of our galaxies. Then again, it could also be something boring, similar to neutrinos, just one singular type of particle that doesn't do much apart from increasing the mass of galaxies. Alright, seriously now, the thing is, assuming the existence of dark matter just because stars don't follow Kepler's or Newton's assumptions is a bit premature in my opinion.
We don't know about gravity any more than we know about dark matter, in the first place. Quantum Field Theorly leaves out gravity entirely. The graviton has never been found. So why are we so darn sure gravitational force ought to diminish exactly by the square of the distance, that if it doesn't it ought to imply there's invisible matter everywhere? Premature speculation.
In fact, it would just be premature speculation if there was a lot of consistency to the observations; but in fact sometimes the observations appear to contradict dark matter to such an extent that they need to postulate a dark energy being repulsive, and which dark energy we also know nothing about; and then we go from premature speculation to downright absurdity.
Yes, sometimes the outermost stars in galaxies seem to go around the galaxy almost as fast as the more internal stars, as if the galaxy were a solid. But if that was due to more mass being present at or around the center of the galaxy than the black holes there could possibly account for, then we'd observe the innermost stars moving far faster than they ought to as well. No matter how much mass you assume, stars should move faster if they are closer to the mass, and more slowly if they are farther away. However, one very common phenomenon observed in spiral galaxies is the "bar". Barred galaxies have a radial bar, like a spoke, and then the spiral arms begin from the ends of those spokes. There is no way to think about stars following gravitational rotations, and yet being more concentrated towards a straight line across the galaxy. And the same thing was observed in the rings of Saturn, with radial stripes sometimes visible. I profess no answer to any of these perplexing phenomena; all I'm saying is that there's a lot we don't know and it doesn't seem to me that inventing dark matter AND dark energy, both undefined, in order to explain why a baseless, centuries-old "law" is not being followed, seems absurd to me. There's an everyday situation where we observe something the likes of what we see with galaxies. Foam on your coffee. You stir the coffee and after a few seconds the foam on top starts to disconnect from the vortex physics and to behave like a solid. So, why should it be so surprising to see the same at the cosmic scale?

THE CHILD WHO UNDERSTOOD GRAVITY
Her name was Sarah, Sarah N. Dipity.

As a child Sarah often overheard her parents,
who were scientists, discuss gravity.

They'd often bring Sarah to their office, where they did experiments
about gravity and discuss them with other teachers and scientists.

They assumed that she wasn't able to understand them,
but in fact Sarah understood more than they did.
It was frustrating that she was too young to talk.

All of them said they didn't really understand gravity,
which was why they were doing all that work.

Somehow Sarah DID understand. She watched them try their experiments,
draw on blackboards, and discuss things well past supper.

Sarah realized, like them perhaps, that if someone could describe
what she knew that it would be helpful. But she also couldn't write.
She watched the adults head off in so many wrong directions.

She worried that they'd try to teach her incorrectly, insist that she learn their ways,
which were often wrong.

So, Sarah decided not to speak or write,
which caused her parents to think that she was slow.

She was perfectly pleasant, just silent.
In her mind she continued to do thought experiments,
using her knowledge of gravity.

Eventually, as we approach a grand unified theory of Life, the Universe and Everything, I think we'll come to understand dark matter as a counterforce to dark energy. We already know that dark energy causes the empty space between galaxies, and especially between galactic clusters, to expand. But at the galactic scale, the space between the stars is normally very dusty, rendering the interstellar medium immune the the cosmological constant which drives galaxies apart. Just as the magnetic force has both attractive and repulsive polarities, perhaps from the galactic scale down, the polarity of the cosmological constant is somehow reversed and it adds itself to the gravitational constant within the vicinity of matter. But because dark energy has a cosmic sphere of influence, rather than adding to G in such a way as to alter local gravitational effects, instead it adds to the galaxy's total mass. To put it another way, it is Archimedes' fabled lever with an arm long enough for a tiny speck of matter to influence the movements of stars across the galaxy.

See Sabine Hossenfelder's latest video about whether "Dark Energy" even exists. The link is at the end of this statement.
The original theory was built on the Saul Perlmutter, Adam Riess Nobel prize winning paper on Type 1A Supernovae. However, it seems there might have been an error in the paper that gave them the Nobel Prize. A new paper was recently published, or "re-published" from 2016 but now again in 2019 which states that the Universe may not be expanding at an "accelerating rate" at all. Yes the universe is expanding from our point of view due to a doppler red shift because of the relative movement of "our" universe" but this paper has now analyzed over 1000 type 1A Supernovae from all across the sky and has found fault with the 1997 paper of Saul Perlmutter and Adam Reiss.
Could they have been wrong after all? This newest paper was peer reviewed and published in a very venerable physics journal and has questioned the conclusions of the original 1997 conclusion that the universe is accelerating. See Sabine Hossenfelder's recent video for more. This is an ongoing study which may lead to a retraction that the universe is indeed "accelerating". In other words, energy and matter were created when the universe first existed and there should be no additional energy added. It's as if Fred Hoyle was correct afterall. Thus the question: Was Saul Perlmutter and Adam Reiss correct? The new paper asks serious questions, which were peer reviewed. The rotation profile of galaxies doesn't fit visible mass and gravitation. IT DOES NOT FOLLOW THAT "it couldn't spin as fast as it does without dark matter". It is not true that "the only thing that can hold [orbiting mass] is gravity." There are many assumptions here, especially that gravity is the sole significant force at cosmic scales. Oh, assuming that we fully know the distribution of mass of the universe (hint: we don't) and that gravity is the sole force acting on everything (it isn't) THEREFORE DARK MATTER!"

Hint: EM fields are not negligeable on cosmic scales. Gravity is, actually. Sure, electric fields and magnetic fields alone are constrained by the cube of the distance, but not all EM phenomena are affected with distance. Photons, for one, should point out how common it is, and collimated plasmas, on the other, should underline its significance as well, as this is the structure of the cosmic web. IT DOES NOT FOLLOW THAT dark matter is necessary at all, and considering how it's increasingly being disproved, did not earn/does not deserve the privilege of being used as working hypothesis.
